description.en: The course introduces modern philosophical logic and its use in the analysis of arguments and natural language semantics.
description.et: Kursus tutvustab kaasaegset filosoofilist loogikat ja selle kasutusviise.

objectives.en: This course introduces the systems of propositional logic and first order predicate logic and their respective model theoretic semantics and deductive systems. It is explained how logic is used to reconstruct and analyse arguments and the semantics of natural language.
objectives.et: Kursuse eesmärk on tutvustada propositsioonilist loogikat ja esimest järku predikaatloogikat. Selgitatakse, kuidas loogikat kasutatakse argumentide ja ka loomuliku keele semantika rekonstrueerimisel ning analüüsimisel.

learning_outcomes.en: The students should acquire a solid understanding of the main notions of formal syntax and semantics. They should acquire the ability to translate natural language sentences into first-order predicate logic, and reconstruct arguments and test their validity. Students should also acquire the ability to carry out proofs in the object language (FOL).
learning_outcomes.et: Kursuse läbinud tudengid mõistavad formaalset süntaksit ja semantikat, suudavad tõlkida loomuliku keele lauseid esimest järku predikaatloogika keelde, rekonstrueerida argumente ja kontrollida nende kehtivust. Üliõpilased peaksid olema omandanud objektkeeles tõestuste läbiviimise oskuse.

notes.et: Lecture videos can be found at Moodle. Seminars will take place in person.

independent_work.et: The once-a-week homeworks consist of two things: a video or set of videos demonstrating the relevant material + some automatically graded practice exercises. Students watch the videos and try out the exercises before the seminar. Then during the seminar we identify what was difficult and improve student understanding of that material. Students do not have to complete every question in each homework. They should do these until they feel that they could pass the corresponding challenge.

description.et: The once-a-week homeworks consist of two things: a video or set of videos demonstrating the relevant material + some automatically graded practice exercises. Students watch the videos and try out the exercises before the seminar. Then during the seminar we identify what was difficult and improve student understanding of that material. Students do not need to complete all homework exercises each week. They should do them until they feel that they could pass the challenge associated with the material of that week.

This course will be graded using a "mastery" system. There will be 12 challenges. Each challenge consists of 2 questions. Each challenge is pass/fail. Grades are assigned according to how many challenges a student passes. With this system, grades reflect how much of the material from the course a student has learnt. An A indicates the student has learnt practically all the material taught. An E indicates that the student has learnt the smallest amount of the material taught.

grade_preconditions.et: Students must pass at least 2 challenges in order to get the minimum grade for passing the course (i.e. E).

To obtain final grade, the following is required:
A: 11 challenges passed
B: 8 challenges passed
C: 6 challenges passed
D: 4 challenges passed
E: 2 challenges passed

debt_elimination.et:
Students can take the challenges whenever they like during the course and up until 2 weeks after the final seminar.
A student gets three "retries" which she can use at any point during the course to retake a challenge, if she wishes. That's not three "retries" per challenge but rather three "retries" across all the challenges. The challenges will be different for different students and will not necessarily be the same if a student chooses to do a retake.
